question_text: What is the Panchayati Raj system?
options: A system where villages elect local leaders to manage community matters
A system where only the state government makes all decisions
A system where only the central government makes all decisions
A system where businesses manage all local affairs
explanation: The Panchayati Raj system is like having elected class monitors who work together to solve school problems at the local level.

question_text: Who leads a village panchayat?
options: The sarpanch (like the class monitor)
The principal (like the school principal)
The chief minister (like the school district head)
The governor (like the state education minister)
explanation: The sarpanch is like the class monitor - they are elected by villagers to lead and represent the community.

question_text: What do panchayat members do in their village?
options: They help solve local problems and make decisions about village affairs
They only collect taxes and give them to the state government
They manage all schools and hospitals in the state
They only work in the city municipal corporation
explanation: Panchayat members work together like student council representatives to solve everyday problems in their neighborhood.

question_text: How often do gram sabha meetings happen in villages?
options: At least once a month where all adults can participate and share ideas
Only when there is a big problem that needs solving
Only once a year during festival time
Never - the panchayat members make all decisions alone
explanation: Gram sabha meetings are like class meetings where everyone gets a chance to speak and share their ideas.

question_text: Which services does a village panchayat typically handle?
options: Maintaining village roads, cleaning, and small water supply
Running state hospitals and major highways
Managing international airports and railways
Operating all schools across the state
explanation: Village panchayats handle local matters like fixing broken paths and keeping the village clean - similar to keeping a classroom tidy.

question_text: What is the difference between a gram panchayat and gram sabha?
options: Gram panchayat has elected representatives; gram sabha includes all village adults
Gram panchayat is for cities; gram sabha is for villages only
Gram panchayat is temporary; gram sabha is permanent
Gram panchayat makes decisions; gram sabha just listens
explanation: Like having student representatives (panchayat) and a class meeting (sabha) where everyone speaks - both are important but different.

question_text: How are panchayat members chosen?
options: Through elections where villagers vote for their representatives
Appointed by the state government
Selected by the central government
Chosen by the district collector
explanation: Voters choose their representatives, just like students vote for class monitor and prefects in school.

question_text: What problems might villagers take to their panchayat for help?
options: Broken streetlights, garbage collection issues, or damaged village roads
Setting up major airports or international border security
Managing national defense and foreign policy
Setting national tax rates and policies
explanation: Local problems like a broken streetlight are taken to panchayat, just like reporting a broken school desk to the class monitor.

question_text: Who provides funds to village panchayats?
options: Central government, state government, and local taxes
Only international organizations
Private companies only
Banks and loan companies only
explanation: Panchayats receive money from different sources, like how school gets funding from education department and local fees.

question_text: What is the role of women in Panchayati Raj system?
options: They can be elected as panchayat members and leaders, including as sarpanch
They can only vote but not be elected
They can only work in the municipality
They can only serve in the state government
explanation: Like electing girl students as class monitors, women can be elected to lead panchayats and make decisions.

question_text: How does the panchayat system help rural development?
options: By bringing government services closer to people and solving local problems
Only by building big factories and industries
Only by managing national parks and wildlife
Only by handling international trade matters
explanation: Panchayats help develop villages by handling local needs, like how a class committee helps improve classroom conditions.

question_text: What happens if panchayat members don't do their work properly?
options: Villagers can question them in gram sabha meetings or vote them out in next elections
Nothing can be done until state government intervenes
Only the central government can take action
They automatically get promoted to higher positions
explanation: If class monitors don't help, students can discuss problems in class meetings and choose new leaders next time.

question_text: What is a municipal corporation?
options: The governing body that manages cities and big towns, like a school administration
A private company that builds houses
A village panchayat for rural areas
A state government office
explanation: Municipal corporations are like school administrations - they manage big areas with many services.

question_text: What is the difference between a municipality and a municipal corporation?
options: Municipality manages smaller towns; municipal corporation manages bigger cities
Municipality is for villages; corporation is for states
Municipality is permanent; corporation is temporary
There is no difference - they are the same thing
explanation: Like the difference between managing a small classroom versus the whole school building.

question_text: Who is the head of a municipal corporation?
options: Mayor (like the principal of a big school)
Chief Minister (like the state education minister)
Governor (like the education commissioner)
Prime Minister (like the national education head)
explanation: The mayor leads the municipal corporation like how a principal manages the whole school.

question_text: What services does a municipality provide?
options: Street cleaning, water supply, garbage collection, and park maintenance
Managing national defense and army
Setting foreign policy and international relations
Managing central banks and national currency
explanation: Municipalities handle everyday city services like keeping streets clean and water flowing - similar to school maintenance.

question_text: How are municipal councilors elected?
options: By people living in specific wards (areas) of the city
Appointed by the state government
Selected by the central government
Chosen by the mayor personally
explanation: People vote for councilors representing their neighborhood, like electing class representatives for different sections.

question_text: What does a municipal corporation do during festivals?
options: Organizes civic arrangements, waste management, and traffic control for celebrations
Only manages government holidays
Handles only religious matters
Organizes only cultural programs
explanation: Municipalities manage practical arrangements during festivals, like how school manages space and crowd during school events.

question_text: How do municipalities collect money for their work?
options: Through property taxes, local fees, and grants from higher levels of government
Only by borrowing money from banks
Only through donations from private companies
Only through international aid and loans
explanation: Municipalities collect money like schools collect fees and receive government funding for operations.

question_text: What role does a municipal corporation play in public health?
options: Ensures clean water, waste management, and basic health facilities in the city
Manages only national health policies
Runs only government hospitals
Handles only international health programs
explanation: Municipalities keep cities healthy by managing clean water and waste - like keeping the school clean and healthy.

question_text: What is the three-tier system of government in India?
options: Village panchayat, district/corporation, and state government - like class, school, and district levels
Central, state, and international governments
Only state and central governments
Village, city, and national governments only
explanation: India has three levels of government working together, similar to how schools have different levels of management.

question_text: How do the three tiers of government work together?
options: Each level handles different responsibilities but coordinates with others for better service
Each level works completely independently without any coordination
Only the central government makes all decisions
Only the state government makes all decisions
explanation: Different levels work together like teachers, principals, and education officers coordinating for better schools.

question_text: What is the role of the state government?
options: To manage state-wide matters like education, health, police, and major infrastructure
To only manage international relations
To only handle defense and military matters
To only manage central government offices
explanation: State governments handle major state affairs like education minister manages all schools in the state.

question_text: Who is the head of state government?
options: The Chief Minister (like the head of district education department)
The President (like the national education minister)
The Prime Minister (like the overall education head)
The Governor (like the state education commissioner)
explanation: The Chief Minister leads the state government like the head of district education office.

question_text: What types of roads does the state government build and maintain?
options: State highways and major roads connecting different cities and districts
Only village roads within panchayat areas
Only international highways between countries
Only roads within municipal corporation limits
explanation: State governments manage major roads connecting cities, like how district office manages major school connections.

question_text: How does state government help municipalities and panchayats?
options: By providing funds, technical help, and policy guidelines for better local services
By taking over all local government functions
By only managing state capital cities
By replacing local governments with state officers
explanation: State governments support local bodies like how central education office helps schools with resources and guidance.

question_text: What services are handled by the state government in schools?
options: Setting curriculum, teacher training, and school infrastructure policies
Managing daily school cleanliness and maintenance
Running individual school functions and activities
Organizing school sports and cultural events
explanation: State governments set rules for education, like the education department setting school policies.

question_text: What role does the state government play in health services?
options: Managing state hospitals, health programs, and disease control across the state
Only managing central government hospitals
Only handling international health issues
Only managing private hospitals and clinics
explanation: State governments run health services like the health department managing all district hospitals.

question_text: How do states get money for their work?
options: From central government grants, state taxes, and local revenue collection
Only from international loans and donations
Only from borrowing money from banks
Only from central government taxes
explanation: States receive money from central government and collect their own taxes, like schools getting funds from education department and collecting fees.

question_text: What is the role of police in the three-tier system?
options: State police maintain law and order; local police support municipalities and panchayats
Only central government police exist
Only local village security guards exist
Police only work during elections
explanation: Police work at different levels - state police for major matters, local police for community safety.

question_text: How do citizens participate in governance at all three levels?
options: By voting in elections, attending public meetings, and reporting local issues
Only by paying taxes
Only by complaining to government offices
Only by participating in protests and strikes
explanation: Citizens participate like students voting, attending class meetings, and reporting problems to teachers.

question_text: What happens when different levels of government disagree?
options: They discuss and find solutions through meetings and legal processes
The higher level always wins without discussion
Citizens must solve the problems themselves
The matter is ignored until it resolves naturally
explanation: Government levels resolve disagreements through discussion, like how teachers and principals resolve conflicts through meetings.

question_text: How are decisions made in democracy?
options: Through elected representatives who listen to people's views and make decisions
Only by appointed officials without people's input
Only by experts without consulting citizens
Only through military orders
explanation: Democracy works through representatives elected by people, like choosing class monitors who represent student views.

question_text: Why do we need different levels of government?
options: Because different problems need different levels of expertise and resources to solve
Because having more governments looks more important
Because people like voting more frequently
Because it creates more government jobs
explanation: Different levels handle different sized problems - like how class monitor, teacher, and principal handle different school issues.

question_text: How does money flow from central to local governments?
options: Central government gives grants to states, which then share with municipalities and panchayats
Directly from central government to all local bodies
Only through loans and interest payments
Only through private sector donations
explanation: Money flows down through the system like school funding from education department to district to individual schools.

question_text: What is the role of five-year plans in governance?
options: To set development goals and allocate resources for national, state, and local projects
To plan only military and defense strategies
To plan only international relations
To plan only central government office buildings
explanation: Five-year plans help governments set goals like schools setting yearly targets for improvement.

question_text: How do states respect local customs and traditions?
options: By allowing local governments to make rules that suit their community needs within national framework
By imposing uniform rules on all communities
By only following central government traditions
By ignoring local customs completely
explanation: States allow local variations like schools respecting different class traditions while following school rules.

question_text: What is the concept of 'cooperative federalism'?
options: All levels of government working together as partners to serve people better
Each level of government competing against each other
Only central government making all decisions
Only state governments making all decisions
explanation: Cooperative federalism is like all school staff working together - teachers, principal, and district officers - for student welfare.

question_text: How do ordinary citizens influence government decisions?
options: Through voting, public consultations, rallies, and feedback to representatives
Only by paying taxes
Only by working in government offices
Only by protesting on the streets
explanation: Citizens influence decisions like students influencing class rules through suggestions, votes, and discussions.

question_text: What happens during elections at different government levels?
options: People vote for their representatives at village, municipal, and state levels
Only central government elections happen
Only state government elections happen
Only village elections happen
explanation: Elections happen at all levels - panchayat, municipal, and state - like class monitor, school captain, and student council elections.
analogy_used: student council elections at different levels

question_text: How do governments ensure transparency in their work?
options: By sharing information through websites, noticeboards, and public meetings
By keeping all information secret from citizens
By sharing information only with government employees
By sharing information only during elections
explanation: Governments maintain transparency like schools sharing information through noticeboards and parent-teacher meetings.

question_text: What is the role of opposition parties in democracy?
options: To question government decisions, offer alternatives, and keep the ruling party accountable
To always support whatever the government decides
To disrupt all government functions
To only criticize without offering solutions
explanation: Opposition parties help democracy like student opposition groups question decisions and suggest better alternatives.

question_text: How do governments handle natural disasters?
options: All levels coordinate - local bodies for immediate help, state for resources, center for major support
Only central government handles all disasters
Only local bodies handle everything
Only international organizations help
explanation: Disaster management involves all levels like school emergencies - class teachers, principal, and district officers working together.

question_text: What is the difference between rural and urban local governments?
options: Rural areas have panchayats; urban areas have municipalities and corporations
Rural areas have no local government
Urban areas have no local government
Both have exactly the same structure
explanation: Different areas need different local governments - villages have panchayats, cities have municipal bodies.

question_text: How do children and young people fit into the governance system?
options: They learn about democracy, can participate in student councils, and become future leaders
They cannot participate until they turn 18
They can only observe but not participate
They should not think about governance at all
explanation: Young people learn democracy through student councils and become informed future citizens and leaders.

question_text: What is the significance of 73rd and 74th Constitutional Amendments?
options: They strengthened local self-government by giving more powers to panchayats and municipalities
They reduced the powers of local governments
They eliminated local governments completely
They only applied to central government
explanation: These amendments made local governments stronger, like giving more powers to class committees and student councils.

question_text: How does the three-tier system help in better service delivery?
options: By bringing government closer to people and solving problems at appropriate levels
By making government more complex and slow
By creating confusion about who does what
By increasing government costs unnecessarily
explanation: Three-tier system improves services by handling problems at the right level, like solving classroom, school, and district issues appropriately.

question_text: What role does technology play in modern governance?
options: Helps in faster communication, online services, and transparency between citizens and government
Replaces all human government officials
Makes governance more complicated
Only helps the rich and educated
explanation: Technology improves governance like digital noticeboards and online platforms improve school communication.

question_text: How do global examples of federal systems compare to India's three-tier system?
options: Like other federal systems, India has multiple levels working together with shared responsibilities
India is the only country with multiple levels of government
All other countries have only one level of government
India's system is completely different from all other countries
explanation: Many countries have federal systems like India, where different levels share responsibilities - similar to international education networks.

question_text: What is the future of local governance in India?
options: More empowerment of local bodies with better technology and citizen participation
Gradual elimination of local governments
Only central and state governments will remain
No changes will happen in the system
explanation: Future of governance involves stronger local bodies using technology, like schools becoming more digital and community-involved.
